THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 24. 1925

HOPKINS MAN NAMED

INTERCOLLEGIATE NEWS

THE ROMAN TOGA"

William S. Rusk, a graduate of Johns Hopkins who
took an M. A. degree here
last year has just been made
assistant Professor of the
History of Art, at Dartmouth College, according to
Dr. David M. Robinson,
Professor of Archaeology at
Hopkins.

Some astounding and truly interesting news about Johns Hopkins was gleaned from an editorial which appeared recently in
the Richmond Collegian. The
subject of the editorial was the
Richmond-Hopkins debate which
was held in Richmond on March
6, and incidently was won by
Hopkins. Mention is made during
the course of the article that, although the student body of Hopkins is only about one-half that of
Richmond this University is considered one of their greatest debating rivals.
It goes still further and states
that "Debating at that school attracts as much attention as football. When debates from the local
institution go to Baltimore to debate, their arguments are heard
by audiences composed by hundreds of graduate and undergraduate students. In view of this
fact it is of vital importance that
students here arrange to attend
the contest tonight." The explanation of the whole editorial
seems to lie in the last sentence.

"The Roman Toga" is the
title of a book by Lillian M.
Wilson, Johns Hopkins, Ph.
D., which has just been published by the Johns Hopkins
Press.

Mr. Rusk is also a graduate of Princeton University
and a former resident of Baltimore. He will spend the
summer in Italy, studying
art in the museums where
he will gather material for
his lectures next fall.
SOPHOMORES LIGHT UP AT
SUCCESSFUL SMOKER
Seventy-five Attend Function.
.Numerals Awarded

Class

The book is the first of a
series to'be printed -by- the
University Press. It is edited by David M. Robinson,
Hopkins Professor of Archaeology. Outside of its interest of a piece of information of Roman life and customs, it is of practical value
in the preparation of costumes for pageants and historical plays.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 24. 1925

HOPKINS MAN NAMED

INTERCOLLEGIATE NEWS

THE ROMAN TOGA"

William S. Rusk, a graduate of Johns Hopkins who
took an M. A. degree here
last year has just been made
assistant Professor of the
History of Art, at Dartmouth College, according to
Dr. David M. Robinson,
Professor of Archaeology at
Hopkins.

Some astounding and truly interesting news about Johns Hopkins was gleaned from an editorial which appeared recently in
the Richmond Collegian. The
subject of the editorial was the
Richmond-Hopkins debate which
was held in Richmond on March
6, and incidently was won by
Hopkins. Mention is made during
the course of the article that, although the student body of Hopkins is only about one-half that of
Richmond this University is considered one of their greatest debating rivals.
It goes still further and states
that "Debating at that school attracts as much attention as football. When debates from the local
institution go to Baltimore to debate, their arguments are heard
by audiences composed by hundreds of graduate and undergraduate students. In view of this
fact it is of vital importance that
students here arrange to attend
the contest tonight." The explanation of the whole editorial
seems to lie in the last sentence.

"The Roman Toga" is the
title of a book by Lillian M.
Wilson, Johns Hopkins, Ph.
D., which has just been published by the Johns Hopkins
Press.

Mr. Rusk is also a graduate of Princeton University
and a former resident of Baltimore. He will spend the
summer in Italy, studying
art in the museums where
he will gather material for
his lectures next fall.

The book is the first of a
series to'be printed -by- the
University Press. It is edited by David M. Robinson,
Hopkins Professor of Archaeology. Outside of its interest of a piece of information of Roman life and customs, it is of practical value
in the preparation of costumes for pageants and historical plays.
